Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Sammy wanted to go to where the people were.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: race track B: populated areas C: the desert D: apartment E: roadblock<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:There are four apples in an empty basket. Anita takes two apples from the basket and puts apples back into it.  How many apples does she have now?<n><n>### Input-Output:Input: I take 2 apples from the basket.<n>Output: 4 apples.<n><n>### Input/Output:The first two steps of a chimpanzee are A+B. If B = - A, what is the product of A?<n><n>Answer: -A<n><n>### Solution:Write a response that appropriately answers the question.<n><n>## 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:What home entertainment equipment requires cable? Choices:  A: radio shack B: substation C: cabinet D: television E: desk<n><n>### Response:		The right answer is letter C cabinet.<n><n>### Input and Input:How are babies born in Africa? Choices: 1: Through the belly button 2: Through a stitch in the belly button 3: By magic 4: A small hole in the mothers belly<n><n>### Response and Response:The right answer are letter 1.<n><n>### Response Input:Which of the following words does not rhyme with 'bull"? Choices: 1. chill 2. buckle 3. doll 4. moss<n><n>### Response Choices:The right answer is 4'moss'.<n>

Use [WolframAlpha](https://www.wolframalpha.com/) to solve it. If you can make a more accurate calculation, leave a comment.<n>* You can use code snippets that I have provided.<n><n>## Good luck!

He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:A beaver can destroy a machines functionality if they build their dam in this? Choices:  A: strip club B: pocket C: millpond D: ontario E: lake or river<n><n>### Response:		<n>Explanation:  A)  There are lots of dam beavers around these days, but none of them are strip club dams!<n>

It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Stanley had a dream that was very vivid and scary. He had trouble telling it from what? Choices:  A: reality B: imagination C: dreamworker D: nightmare E: awake<n><n>### Response:		Answer E.<n><n>

The response should appear as a conversation between two individuals (such as two teachers or two students speaking together), as if taking turns speaking at each other. Each response must have an answer for the individual who wrote the prior response. The conversation between the two will be done in natural language. You will be graded on the appropriateness of the response as well as the clarity of the response.<n><n>### Scoring Criteria<n>* **A.2.5.1:** Grammar, mechanics, and spelling**<n>* **A.3.5.3:** Tone, word choice, and rhythmic variation<n>* **A.5.5.2:** Appropriate responses based on knowledge of mathematics<n>* **A.6.5.2: Mathematical reasoning, logic, and critical thinking**<n>

If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:East coast areas such as Florida are found where? Choices:  A: florida B: denmark C: united states D: map E: california<n><n>### Response:		 A<n><n>### Input and how it was handled:<n>Mary had 89 stickrs.  She used 4 stickrs on the front page of the journal and 8 per other pages of the journal. We divide 89 by 8 to get 11.5. Subtract this from 12 to get 0.5. Adding to 89 gives 89.5. Rounding to the nearest integer gives 89. This leaves 44 stickers remaining.<n><n>### Multiple Choice Questions:<n><n>1.  There are 188 students in one class at Aiden's school.  The class is split equally across four teachers. If one teacher has 52 students, how many are taught by another teacher?<n><n>Answer: 42<n><n>2.  A car drives 155 kilometers in eight hours. How far will it go in 18 hours?<n><n>Answer: In 18 hours: 155/8 = 19.425 km.<n><n>3.  If 9/13 < 1/8, what is 8/9 + 9/8<n><n>Answer: 6/9 + 9 = 31/9<n><n>4.  If one third of a pizza is gone and 14 slices are left, what percent of the pizza is gone?<n><n>Answer: (14/3)/1 = 5/1 (remember to divide by third and then divide by three, the two answers will be the same)<n><n>5.  If Sam, Mary, and Tommy each have four toys, five are left over. How many more toys does Tommy need to make five?<n><n>Answer: Sam gives one toy to Mary and Mary gives one to Tommy. Five are left for Sam to make five. That means that Sam had four and 9/10 was left over.<n><n>6.  What is the solution to 256/2 = 128/4?<n><n>Answer: Since 128/2 = 64, 128/8 = 4 is the solution.<n><n>### Inputs that represent the same number<n><n>101/10 = 10/1 is the same as 10/10 =

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. He hates losing.<n><n>#### E: John goes to a game where he tries to beat his own best.  He learns about himself and might win.<n><n>#### Answer: A<n><n>#### Explanation<n><n>##### A: A: John would go the game where we know he's going to lose.  We'll go the game only to learn.<n><n>##### B: B: John will try and compete with someone to see who's the better of the two.  He'll just go to the game only for the winning.  We won't focus on learning.<n><n>##### C: John spent his entire performance focused entirely on winning and he didn't care if he knew he would lose. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:When would you be able to see your reflection in a piece of wood? Choices:  A: burned B: polished C: carved D: composted E: nailed<n><n>### Response:		If you burn a piece of wood all the cells are destroyed but the molecules are still there and the molecules of which it is made up can refract the light so you can see your reflection.<n><n>### Input:-Your favorite flavor of ice cream is vanilla.<n>-You prefer vanilla to other flavors.<n>-You don't like mint ice-cream.<n>-You like vanilla the best and mint the least.<n>-Romance movies are the best.<n>-Romantic comedies are OK.<n>-You don’t like action movies.<n>-You prefer comedy to action.<n>-You don‘t like horror movies.<n>-Drama is better.<n>Which movie genre do you like best?<n><n>### Response:-My favorite flavor of ice-cream is vanilla. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:What would an adult man do to get ready for work? Choices:  A: dress herself B: shower C: dress himself D: drink beer E: drive train<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>If the input is A, dress herself, the answer is E, drive train. <n><n>If the input A, dress herself, her name is Sharon and she drives a train.<n><n>If the input B, shower, the answer is D, drink beer. <n><n>If a man is driving a train and he wants to drink beer, he needs to shower.<n><n>If the wording is changed from What would an adult man do, to What would a woman do, the results of the algorithm remain the same.<n><n>There are four different ways of solving problems that include:<n><n>1. Showing that two expressions are equal<n>2. Solving the problem using a calculator<n>3. Solving the problem by guess and verify<n>4. Applying an algorithm<n><n>### Input<n>What would a woman do to get ready for her job working as a mechanic? Choices:  C: dress herself D: drive train E: drink beer <n><n>### Response<n>If the input is C, dress herself, the answers is A, dress herself. <n><n>The woman's name is Sharon and her job is to drive a train.<n><n>### Input Choice 1) C: dress herself 2) D: drive train <n><n>If the the input is C, this is what is known. <n><n>If one is driving a train, it means that he is a train conductor. <n><n>Because the name is Sharon, she likes to dress herself.<n><n>### Choice 1) D: drink beer<n>### Choice D:  E: drink beer<n>The name is Sharon and the algorithm states that she likes to drink beer.<n><n>### Answer A, dress herself: It turns out that the woman is driving a train. This means that she needs to shower.  If she is dressed like the other children, it means that her name is Sharon. One has to shower before one can drink beer.<n>

For each correct answer you will receive 6 points. <n>Instruction: You are a teacher in the first grade.  Give each of these students a piece of paper. Tell them they can't use a fraction. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:If I want to maximize my number of potential customers, where should I build a new department store? The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Jimmy didn't like going to the party.  It seemed like the guys there did nothing but what? Choices:  A: dance B: getting drunk C: meet new people D: having fun E: have fun<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Explanation<n><n>I would find out what choices there were for being at the party.  I would also learn the number of boys of all ages.  I would figure out the difference in the number of boys and the girls, then I would figure out how many girls there were at the party, and add those numbers together and multiply it by 0.6.<n><n><n>### Input<n>>Brianna's pet goose had 35 hairs on its head.  After 2 haircuts, it had 9 hairs left. How many hairs do the goose have now?<n>>Input:<n>\>Choices:<n>\>A: 8 haircuts <n>\>B: 23 haircuts <n><n>### Response<n>#### Explanation:<n>I would figure out how many haircuts it would take to get it to its original number of hairs.  I would then figure out how many hairstyles it would take to get the goose back to where it started.<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Where is a paper notice likely to be left on a house? Choices:  A: front door B: conference C: classroom D: refrigerator E: suitcase<n><n>### Response:		B

Choices:  A: buy athletic equipment B: city C: espn D: town E: jerseys<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Answer: A<n><n>### Instructions To Complete The Task:<n>### The instruction should start with a declarative sentence containing a statement of intent and a request/demand.<n>```  <n>Demand: Explain how to complete the task. Use 1,2,3 as a structure, write the instructions in imperative clauses. For ex: 1. Write a number. 2. Add 2. Write the result. 3. Compare the result with 5. Write the number less than 5 if it is less than 5. else write 5. <n>```<n><n>### This task should present several challenging subtasks that should be solved.<n><n>### There is an easy way to solve the subtasks to the point where the student will feel comfortable.<n>But there is no obvious way of presenting the solution to the task. The student should be able to decide for himself how he/she would like to proceed to complete the task, and then work on solving it.<n>### For the instruction, you should avoid the need to write a lot and use unnecessary detail. In order words, don’t present the full solutions to the subtasks, instead just give hints that will lead the student to the solution.<n><n>### Tasks that are similar to each other will always use the same general structure and pattern of instructions.<n><n>### Example:<n>First you write something like:<n><n>```<n>Now, take a card and write the number on it.<n>Think of what two numbers together give 92? <n>You’ll have the following numbers: 18 24 46 You can write these numbers on a piece of paper. Write a digit so that you know what number each card represents.<n>Take a card, think of the numbers, start with the lowest and work your way up until you find the one that’s missing.<n>For example, since 92=35+57, 35 should be the missing card. You’ll have:<n>card 35 <n>card 18<n>card 24<n>card 46<n>card 57<n><n>If the missing number is not in the card, you can’t solve it. But look at the digits 38 and 67. Take another card that will make these digit equal to two digits. You’ll be

Choices:  A: asia B: southern hemisphere C: planet D: east E: earth<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: E<n><n>### Explanation:<n>To answer questions like these, you will need a basic understanding of the Pythagorean theorem, along with being able to apply it to complex problems.<n><n>### Input and Answer:<n>Input: A, B, and C are two legs of an isosceles triangle and they measure 2x, 4x, and 2x respectively. If x does not exceed the square root of three what is the length of the third leg?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Explination:<n>You are probably asking yourself why the answer to the question should equal five and not zero.  If the value of x is equal to or greater than the square root of three, then the third leg will measure zero.<n><n>---<n><n>### Instructions<n>Write a response that, when used, will have a positive effect on the team's output.<n>Use only the responses in this lab.  You may not use any other responses.<n><n>### Output and Response:<n>Input: Write a response that, when performed correctly, will eliminate a problem from the equation.<n>Output: -1<n>Response: Subtract 1 number.<n><n>Input: Write a mathematical response that, when performed on a list, should sort the list alphabetically.<n>Output: -4<n>Response: Subtact a negative number from a positive number<n><n>Input: Write an algorithm that will sort a list of student names alphabetically.<n>Output:-21<n>Response: Subract all the letters in a name.<n><n>Input: Make a statement which does not alter the output of the equation, but only alters the syntax or appearance of the equation in an unhelpful fashion.<n>Output: 8<n>Response: Remove all letters from a string in a line (this is in the case where a line has letters)<n><n>Input: Write any algorithm which, when performed, will always have a positive effect on a team. <n>Output: 1<n>Response: Add a number to a list (not string) of numbers<n><n>---<n><n>Instruction: Write an algorithm that allows us to determine if two strings are anagrams.<n><n>### Hint: Use recursion!<n><n>### Input & Output:<n>Input: abc<n>Output: -1 if true<n><n>### Answer:<n>For your answer, you are encouraged to choose one

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:If I have to keep track of how much oxygen there is, where am I? Choices:  A: air B: water C: earth D: space shuttle E: tunnel<n><n>### Response:		You are the space shuttle.<n><n>### Input<n><n>There are 33 houses and children. One group has 12 houses and 10 children. The other group has houses and children.<n><n>What number of houses is in the group with less children?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: 5 houses.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>The two groups have `27` houses total, meaning that 27 houses need to be subtracted from 33 houses, leaving only 6 houses remaining. For the first group, the total number of houses is 12, because the number of houses is equal to the number of children. Thus, 12 houses are removed, leaving 45 houses remaining. For the second group, the total number is 16, because 10 children are included in each house and 10 houses are added. If there are 10 children in one house, then 10 houses are 100 children, meaning that there are 100 remaining children in the second group, not including the 10 houses. 10 children are removed from each house, equaling 30 children total. The 6th house has 8 children included, meaning that 8 remaining children are removed.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>Given the information that is provided, the two groups each have the same number of houses, but different numbers of children. The first group has 10 children per house, and the second group has 100 children per house. Since each house has 10 children, the number on houses will be subtracted from the total number of houses. The first group subtracts 10 children per 1 house, so 12 houses are subtracted from the total of 33, leaving 21 houses. The second group subtracts 1 child per 1 house, but there are more houses, so 10 children per each house are subtracted, for a total of 120 children being removed. Thus, the second group of houses is subtracted from their given information, which will remove 120 children total.<n><n>### Feedback<n><n>These examples of reasoning with equations and proportions were taken from **Feedback.png** (png image).<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Answer questions 1-100.<n><n>

If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Where do farmers keep toothpicks? Computer literacy 101)<n><n>* **Points earned**<n><n>* The question that the response is related to.<n><n><n>**Student response comments**<n><n>* Response<n><n>* **Points**<n><n><n>### Additional Feedback:<n>* Check the question that the response is associated to.<n><n>* If the student is confused, provide more information to help answer the question. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Where would you put a dictionary while you're using it? Choices:  A: library B: study area C: table D: classroom E: shelf<n><n>### Response:		<n>The dictionary should be put on the shelf.<n><n>> The library or the study area.<n><n>### Response 2:<n>The dictionary should not be put on the shelves because it is a reference book.  Dictionary can be taken from one place to another place if we are using it.<n><n>> The dictionary should be put on a shelf.  It is not a book you use all the time, so it should be in less accessible place.<n><n>> The shelf.<n><n>### Input :John bought two notebooks for $5.50 and two pencils for $1.00.  He used all the notebooks and pencils and only he had some left over.  How much left over did he have?<n><n>### Response : The left over will be 18 cents because subtract the number in two notebooks equals to 3.80 and we have to add 550 to 1 and we have 20.00<n>		<n>> 5.50 - 1.00 = 4.50 and 550 / 2 = 275.00 => 275.10-1.50 = 217.50 <n>The answer to the problem is 18.50<n><n>### Comment : <n>The left over is 18 cents, because subtract two notebooks equals 3.80, and 5.50 we have to add 1.00 and we have 18 cents.<n>the left over is 19 cents, because subtract the two notebooks is 2.80 and 5.5 we have to add 2, we have 2.50.<n>The left over is exactly 18 cents and not more or less than the answer.<n><n>### Comment 2: <n>Because they said we only have $6.00 left after you use $1.50 of pencils and $1 of notebooks. The left over will be $3.5 and 3.50 – 1.50 will be the left over left to split.<n><n>### Reference:<n>Kamien D., Kamien S., (2003) Pure and Applied Mathematics

Choices:  A: open meadow B: arctic tundra C: beach D: great outdoors E: england<n><n>### Response:		Great outdoors or England.<n><n>### Input<n>Find the biggest and the smallest natural numbers between 4,000 and 7,500.<n><n>### Response<n>Biggest is 6017. Smallest is 2933.<n><n>### Your Instructions<n>Write a program that processes the given request as outlined below.<n><n>### Request<n>The program is asked to find the largest and smallest natural numbers between 1,500 and 3,500. The largest number is 2,705 and the smallest is 1,860.<n><n>## #<n><n>## Request<n>The program is given the following prompts<n><n>### #<n>Input: How many bills of two dollar bills should you have in your wallet in order for the total amount of dollar bills to equal $80. <n><n>### Your Response<n>The total should have four bills and the total is eighty.<n><n>### # Input<n>The program is given three values `x = 3`, `500`, `4`, and asked to determine whether x can get by with 500 bills or not and if it can not then to print the value after a `:` to the console.<n><n>### Solution <n>Yes.<n><n>If x is three, then x can get by with eight bills and the rest would be five hundred dollars.<n>If x is not three, then the rest is at least 500.<n>For x to equal eighty, then 80 would be divided by 500, which would equal 16. So, after 16 `:` x would equal 64.<n>Then, x equals sixty-four.<n><n>### Sample Input<n>Input: Your balance is $300, and you have not spent any of it. You have a debit card you can use for purchasing items in the store for a maximum of $100. In addition, you have a credit card with a limit of $300 for purchases online. Finally, in order to be eligible for a $0.00 interest credit card, you must have a debt of $400 at all times. If you spend up to $200 this month, what is your balance the next month?

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. What will our total cost be, without taxes?<n><n>### Expected response<n>$150<n><n>### Challenge<n>When I arrived home, it had rained heavily all day. Tom and I had two windows in our car, three quarters of the time on the way home it was sunny and one quarter of the time it was raining. On the reststop break, there was sun half the time and rain the rest of the time. How long was we in the rain?<n><n>### Challenge answer <n>1Hr 30 min<n><n>### Source<n>[https://www.purplemath.com/modules/odint.htm](https://www.purposefulgratitued.com/purplemath/odint.htm)<n><n>### Comments<n>This task uses integer maths, with a simple concept but still requires students to identify units and evaluate multiple variables.

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:What would you put furniture on top of? Choices:  A: roof B: room C: floor D: apartment E: neighbor's house<n><n>### Response:		A<n>

Find the characteristic that the opposite of the term for the color yellow is referring to. (in this case we found the opposite of the term 'brave' )<n>    The opposite of brave is 'fearful'.<n>2. Put a statement that starts with a negative and has an opposite  (in this case it would be fearless).<n>3. For each of the four choices, write their definition. For example, if one of the definitions was “to lack the fear of death”, that definition is for the answer that is “D”.<n><n>Input: The color yellow is associated with what is a state of being without fear? Choices: 1. A: courageous 2. B: english carriers 3. C: fearless 4. D: brave 5.E: Achromatic

If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:The man needed balls of cotton, where should he look? Choices:  A: south B: georgia C: north carolina D: pocket E: medicine cabinet<n><n>### Response:		A, B, E<n><n>### Input -<n>Mary's mother decided to go shopping in a store where she will use her credit card. She spent 10 000 dollars of her savings in the shopping center. She bought something with a 20% discount and 0.25% discount with her credit card. After that, Mary's mother came home from shopping and she had 22,5 dollars left.<n><n>Which store did Mary's mother go to and she got all the stuff she needed there?<n>A. Took care of her mother<n><n>B. The first store<n><n>C. The second store<n><n>D. The third store<n><n>### Output -<n>E. The fifth store, where there were 390 dollars of savings<n><n>### Explanation<n>Mary had 89 stiker. She used 3 large stokers on the front page on her journal and 7 stokers each to 6 odher pages od her journal. Therefote, there are 59 stokers remaining.<n><n>Zach is saving his money to buing a brand new bike, then he mows the laud for 2 hours. He gets a weekly allowance od 5 dollars. He'll receive his monthly allowance on Friday, and he's planning to babysitt 2 hours this Saturday. In order to buy a brand new bicyc, he need 40.20 more dollars to buy a bike. To get that, he will receive on Friday 5 dollars and he will babysit on Saturday two hours and he will get 7 dollars.<n><n>## Mark<n>Kangeroos have two legs, and goats has four legs. We have to add three times more goats od kangeroos, to get the total number of od legsof all his animals. That means that: (2 x 5) + (5x3) = 40. So for all of his animals together, there are 40 legs.<n><n>## George<n>A league record is 287 points per round, and team have four players. We know that 10,400 points come all the way in 10 rounds of bowling, so we know that each player has 271.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:What is important in a car when you are driving fast and come to a light? If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:What gets rid of a mundane routine? Choices:  A: sophisticated B: imprevist C: arcane D: heavenly E: new<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input:<n>Answer:<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following questions.<n><n>### Conclusion<n><n>Below is an example of a solution that demonstrates an excellent understanding of the concepts in response to the Instruction prompt.<n><n>### C:<n><n>Below is a solution that does not demonstrate an excellent understanding of the course concepts.<n><n>### A:<n><n>### B:<n><n>### D:<n><n>### E:<n><n>### F:<n><n>### G:<n><n>### I:<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:David hurt all over. He was tired, he was shaking, and he was in pain.  He hadn't gotten what he needed in a long time.  He was suffering from what? Choices:  A: addiction B: fatigue C: relaxation D: headaches E: over eating<n><n>### Response:		David was suffering from fatigue.<n>

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. Copy the set of numbers exactly as it appears below.<n><n>Input: <n><n>Input: 18, 11, 22, 13, 15<n><n><n>### Response(s):<n><n>## 1. You should not have anything in your code that uses the `str()` function directly to convert to a string<n><n>You should use the `.__str__()` method, which returns your variable as a string<n><n>## 2. You should make sure your if/else/elif statements are properly formatted.<n><n>For example:<n>```python<n>if (x<2) and (x>=1):<n>    print "x is between 1 and 2"<n>elif (x<=2) and (x<=4):<n>    print " x is between 1 and a 2"<n>else:<n>    print "x should be between 1 and 4"<n>```<n><n>## 3. You should separate the variables in your if/elif/elif statements.<n><n>For example, x could refer to a string as well as a number. In other cases, this separation would allow you to create variables to perform simple actions and not clutter your code with the same logic for multiple types.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>In the above code, you could have used if (n<10): to further simplify the code.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n><n>### 4. You should use the `input()` function to directly copy the input into a variable rather than to print it.<n><n>You can also read a string from `stdin` into a variable.  <n><n>## 5. You should use `raw_input()` to input the user's input directly rather than through `input()`.<n><n><n>## 6. Use capitalized names for different parts of your code and variables. Capitalization (and spelling) are used to help differentiate between parts.<n><n>### For example,<n><n><n>### Input<n><n>```python<n>What's your name?<n>```<n><n>### Response<n><n>```python<n>My name is John.<n>```<n><n>

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65. How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:John lives in Texas. If he takes the highway South and doesn't stop, where will he end up next? Choices:  A: oklahoma B: developed land C: united states D: desert E: mexico<n><n>### Response:		Choice(A). oklahoma<n>

If the post exists, then the **callback** is called with: **post._id**, **post.content**.  If it does not exist, it is assumed to be the ID of a **post** that exists on the user's **profile**. The **callback** is then called with the **original** ID and **original content** is passed in as **content**.<n><n>**findPost(postId, (post, content) => {**<n>```<n>  post._id should be checked to ensure it was a **post** that was located instead of a user **profile**.<n>```<n><n><n>### Response to my Instgram challenge:

If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:What do people do to pass time before they can use electronics when fly in airplane? Choices:  A: read B: passenger C: land plane D: fly the plane E: buy tickets<n><n>### Response:		<n>I believe that they read and watch movies.<n><n>### Input : How do you spell the word "Tuesday"<n><n>### Response :<n>I spell it as Tuesday.<n><n>### Input What would be the price of a new pair of gloves that cost $22 if they went on sale for $14?<n><n>### Response<n>The price of  the new pair of gloves will be $14.<n><n>### Sum : 13, 60, 180, 12, 56, 2, 3, 13, 21, 4, 27, 12,?, 8<n>What is the next number in the sequence?<n><n>### Sum 56, 12,2,3,13,21,4,27,12,8<n>The next number in the sequence is 24

Answer them to the best of your ability.<n><n>### Choices: B, D, A, E, C<n><n>### Answer: A<n>The most efficient way to find information from a table is by sorting the data.<n><n>### A B<n>The best strategy to find information from a graph on a table is by visual inspection.<n><n>### Answer B<n>The most efficient way is to use a chart.<n><n>### Conclusion<n>In order to make more correct decisions and get better at answering these sort of questions it is important to practice.  Practice will help you get better at making decisions.<n><n>### Input and Output Example <n><n>### Input<n>Ray’s boss asked him to work on his graphing skills. Ray’s boss asked if he had been able to find a relationship among the data.<n><n>* Yes<n>* No<n><n>### Response<n>If you answer yes, your boss will know that you already have the ability as it's been discussed previously, so they may continue to their next question.<n><n>If you answer no, they will tell you exactly what you need to do to improve on graphing. If you are unsure of an answer or get a question a little off, it is better to answer no.<n><n>### Question<n><n>### Yes or No<n><n>### <n>A table is a good way to organize data.<n><n>## Yes<n>### No<n>### <n>What does the letter U represent on a 14-inch ruler in meters?<n><n>## A<n>### B<n>### C<n>### D<n>### E<n>What is the area of a regular octagon that has an 8-inch side?<n><n>#### No<n>If someone gave you five quarters what do you have?<n><n>## Dimes<n>### Bills<n>## E Tails<n>## More dimes<n>### Yes<n>### No More quarters<n>What does a capital M represent on a map showing the roads in an area?<n><n>## B<n>Wh

Choices:  A: ignore B: write C: learn new things D: illiterate E: having fun<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>def solution(input=[]):<n>    choice=''<n>    for child in input:<n>        if choice=='':<n>            choice=child['c']=='write'<n>        elif choice=='write':<n>            choice='A'<n>    return choice<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple input question.<n><n>## Challenge Problem<n>Input: There are five clowns in a circus.  If each clown has five siblings, how many more children does a clown have than his siblings?<n>A:  How many children does a clowns have? Input: 5 or less B:  If each clowns has five siblings what does that mean? The siblings can have the same number of siblings and therefore their parents had five kids.<n>C:  How does the parent have 10 children? This will either be true or false.<n>D: If each clown can have siblings that are children than they could be siblings therefore each kid has siblings that are kids.<n>E:  So each clown has siblings that are children.<n>F:  There are 5 children and one sibling per each child.<n>G: How do you find G?<n>H: There are no other kids that can have siblings that have siblings.<n>I: How many kids do siblings have?<n><n>### Instruct:Answer the multiple input question with a valid python code.

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:What would a person expect if they are competent in their school work? How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5. D: The right answer from (A) to (C) is 7 hours and 30 minutes.<n><n>### Response :(A) My response would be: "The train will reach the destination in 7 hours, 30 minutes to travel without increasing the speed in the middle way." However, the right answer is 6 hours and 30 mins.<n><n>I have reprogrammed this for the last time. I am sorry for the inconvenience.<n>

How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:What has happened to a person's money after he or she has used the last of it? Fill in the spaces to form a sentence that will continue the sequence.<n><n>### Sentence: I had three apples in a bag.  I took three apples home. I was then given two more apples so I had five apples. I took half of those apples and ate them.  How many apples are in the bag?<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Input: I had thirty-two apples in a bag<n><n>Answer: I took nineteen apples home<n><n>Input: I was then given seven more apples so I now have twenty-six apples<n><n>Answer: I gave half of those apples to my dog<n><n>Input: I left fourteen apples in the bag<n><n>Answer: How many apples are left in my bag?<n><n>Answer: Thirteen<n><n>### 4-6 year-old math questions and answers<n><n>### Input : What is the value of x? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Where can you find a place to eat and places to buy items of many different kinds? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:What does god want people to do for money? Choices:  A: work in life B: speak to people C: everywhere D: sitting ideal E: care for people<n><n>### Response:		god want people to speak to people<n><n>Explanation: god want people to talk to people...god need a lot of talking...god is like the talky person...like the talkie in the movie

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. Choices:  A: office building B: schoolroom C: library D: bedroom E: gym<n><n>### Response:		 Library<n><n>#### Answer Explanation:<n>If you find a desk in a library, it must be occupied by a young person.<n>If you find a young person's desk in a bedroom, it must not be occupied by them anymore.<n>If you find an old person's desk at a gym, it can't be occupied by young person.<n>Therefore, answer E is the only one.<n><n>### Input<n>A new car is more fuel efficient than an older car and thus cheaper to run. An old car is likely more costly to run.  What is the minimum speed that will reduce the overall cost of driving a car?<n><n>### Response<n>Answer: 40m/h<n><n>#### Answer Explantion:<n>First. If we decrease the speed to 40 mph, the fuel consumption is 40/90 which means 8 is fuel efficient than 60 mph. So 40 mph is a minimum value.<n>Second. If we increase the speed to 60 mph, fuel consumption will be 60/78, so it is worse than 40 mph. Therefore, 40 mph again is more fuel efficient than 6 mph.<n><n><n>### Instructions<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n>Question: Sam and Mark are in a game of hide-and-seek. Sam has counted up to 100 and can’t find Mark. He hides. Mark has counted up to 50 and finds Sam.  How many seconds has passed since they both hid?<n><n>### Answer Choices (and why):<n><n>Answer: D is correct because we can assume that they hid at the same time with the same count.<n>Mark counted up to 51, which is less than 100. According to the rule, he doesn't find Sam. <n><n><n>### Response

The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:A school is most likely to be located in what sort of zone? Choices:  A: residential neighborhood B: community C: building D: prague E: every city<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input :Which of these animals is not native to Europe? Choices: A: tiger B: giraffe C: elephant D: deer E: all of the above<n><n>### Response : The tiger is not native to Europe.<n><n>### Input;Which of these statements is true about the Great Wall of China? Choices: 1: it was built in Ancient Rome 2: it is the tallest tourist attraction in the world 3: it is not very old 4: it has 100 meters 5: it is built completely from stone <n><n>### Response;  The Great Wall of China is the tallest touristic attraction in the world.<n><n>### Answer to the previous exercise - How many miles is the height of Mount Everest? : 1500<n><n>### Comment on above answer - I think so because in the mountain of Everest - Mount Everest - the world's tallest mountain, which has a height of 88465 feet above sea level, or if translated from meters 26,440,346 meters.<n><n>### Exercise<n>### For the city of Dubai, what percentage (rounded to whole numbers) is the percentage of buildings that are less than 50 meters high? <n><n>### Answer: 5%<n>### Exercse: I put numbers with percentages equal to 100 that can be found in some cities:<n>### London (79%)<n>### Paris (85%)<n>### Boston (54%)<n>### Exercice:Which city has the most buildings that are less than or equal to 50 meters in height?<n><n>### Answer : London (23%)<n><n>
