Each person will take as many coins as they want out of the total. Two of the students take half of the coins. The remaining two students will each take one third of the coins. How many coins will each student get?<n><n>## Instructions;A student had $3 in his pocket. His father gave him $5. His mother gave him $9. Then he received $4.60 for doing a job. Write a sentence that describes his money state.<n><n>### Request:Answers a question with at least three sentences<n><n>### State: $5.10<n><n><n>### Request;A sentence with a math equation.<n><n>### State;$5.10 + $5.60 = $11.06<n><n>### Request :Use a conditional sentence to describe an assumption.<n><n>### Statements :If I didn't have an apple, then I could have a apple.<n><n>### Input  :Write a question based on the statement.<n><n>### Question :How many apples do you possess?<n><n>### Input   :Three students each have one of the two numbers in question 3. If they each take a step backwards, what number do they all have in common?<n><n>### Answer; Eight<n><n>### Input ; If a student's income is decreased by $5 every night for one week, how much will his income be reduced for the week?<n><n>### Statement ;$5 + $5 + $5 +$
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:What is a great place to lay in the sun? Choices:  A: in the basement B: west C: solar system D: beach E: beans<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Reference: https://learn.co/lessons/math-functions-and-syntax<n>

How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Where is a bald eagle safe? Choices:  A: pine tree B: open country C: in washington D: wildlife refuge E: sky<n><n>### Response:		The bald eagle is safe in the sky.<n><n>### Inputs:Which is the best way to get to a beach in the summer? Choices:  a: drive a car  b: bike to the bus depot and take bus b107  c: walk there  d: take the bus b45 and go to the beach park in the summer<n><n>### Response : The best way to get to the beach is to take the bus that takes you there.<n><n>### Output : The bald eagle is not safe and the best way to take the bus is to use a phone.<n><n>### Task 1:  Write a program that defines a function named getGrade(score, number) that takes as arguments the student’s score and number of problems he or she got right, and returns the student’s grade. Make sure the variable score is of “const” type<n>### Input:  Input test string:  "Hi my name is John and I was born on March 21, 1929, in San Francisco, and I studied with Charles Darwin and Alfred Russell Wallace. I have one of the world's biggest and most impressive collections of butterflies, shells and stuffed birds and animals. I have also a collection of rocks, minerals and fossils. I also work with Darwin on a joint scientific paper about orchids in 1877."<n><n>### Solution:<n>```<n>/* Function Name:<n>const getGrade(score){<n>	<n>		score = <n>		if(score>=30){<n>			grade= "A"<n>		}else if(score>=15 && score<=29){<n>				grade=  "B"<n>		} else if<n>				score < 15{" C"}<n>		return grade<n>	}		<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Input : <n>Input test string:  "What do you mean, 'the other shoe dropped?' Can you explain what you meant?" <n><n>### Solution :<n>```<n>console.log(getGrade(35));<n>console.log(String(getGrade("23")));<n>```

How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:What is a person chatting with friends likely hoping to accomplish? Choices:  A: gathering of information B: communication C: feel relaxed D: kill boredom E: social bonding<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n><n>### Instructions:Select one the three choices below.<n><n>### Choice:A,<n><n>Sometimes the most important step in a scientific discovery is to come up with a question. For example, scientist Marie Curie found that uranium had properties that radioactivity. She did not know what radiation was when she discovered it, but she asked questions that led to the development of the field of nuclear science.<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Choices:B,C<n><n>### Response.<n>### Below is an example of how a student should answer the question. <n>Scientists typically ask a question or make a prediction and then test that prediction. For example, the scientist who asked the original question about birds and the dinosaur was not satisfied when the initial answer was that birds come from dinosaurs. They knew they were on to something, so they asked another question. They came up with more experiments and asked a more specific question about what kinds of dinosaurs birds most likely came from.<n><n><n>## Classify:<n><n>### Instuction:Classify the sentence as a statement, question, exclamation sentence, or command.<n><n>### Statement:The bird is beautiful.<n><n>### Question:Tom looked for his wallet.<n><n>### Command:Shake out the blanket, please!<n><n>### Exclamation:What a pretty bird!<n><n>### ResponseStatement:<n>In statements, you don’t ask a question.<n><n>## Statement:Liz’s father’s favorite hobby is swimming, but not mine.<n><n>### Classification:Statement<n><n>### ResponseExclamation:<n>Liz's dad is a big swimmer.<n><n>### Analysis:<n>If you say, “I need to take my cat to the vet,” that’s not a question. You are making a statement and then making a request.  It is still a statement, but it is a statement with an added element. (The same goes for commands. They may have an added element of explanation.)<n><n>### Command<n>When you give a command,<n>1. you use _must_<n>or _must_ when the command is directed at a group<n>2. it includes an explanation of the command to be followed <n>

Choices:  A: music store B: dance hall C: orchestra D: symphony E: tennessee<n><n>### Response:		<n>In order for the fiddle to play, the fiddle need a place to rest. In addition, a fiddle is commonly played to add some cheerfulness to any place like a music store, dance hall or even a symphony. Therefore, one will find a fiddle playing at the music store, dance hall and symphony which are the common play grounds of the fiddle. <n><n>### Input :There are four houses painted different colors. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Can you name a good reason for attending school? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Where would you see people in uniform playing with a ball? The function should be called on the strings in the array that have been passed to it, and should not search for the string more than once. Example usage:<n><n>```ruby <n>puts "I found it at " + find('cat') + "th index.\n"<n>puts "I tried but could not find it.\n"<n>putts "Try again with another string.\n" <n>puts "Try again with another word.\n" <n>input = gets<n>find words.join(" ")<n>puts "\nI found it at " <n>```<n><n>## **Output example:**<n><n>```ruby<n>I found it at 2nd index.<n>I tried but could not  find it.<n>Try again with another word.<n>Try again with cat.<n>I found it at the 2nd index. <n>```<n><n>

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. The audience was awestruck at the final curtain call because they all stood up and applauded. <n><n><n>### Demystifing:If 2/6 of a number is a whole number, that means it will be a multiple of six and can be divided in whole numbers.<n><n>### The task is to ask the user how much they would pay an item with a maximum of 10 and a minimum of 2, and a total of 12. It will give the answer and allow the user to confirm it and end with all three correct choices if they are in the correct range. <n><n><n><n>### Input and Response:<n>Such a cool price I would pay you for this amazing object, $8,9$ to be exact.<n><n>### In the above scenario the answer would be chosen in the response and if the user chose 2 it would print out the answer to be sure that the user did not choose out of the choices. If the user is in the range the question prints out and that is followed with the response.<n><n><n><n>## Problem Solutions:<n><n>### Problem:What are the missing values in the range when the median of a number is 123, 125, 12?<n><n>### Explanation:The median of a given data set is defined as "the number that divides the data set in two, of the same size. Half of the data set before and after its median."<n><n>### Exemplification:<n>### I will explain how to do this process.<n><n>### First we are going to make the data set we will be given and using the formula to find the median of the data with the following data.<n>* 6, 123,  8, 125<n><n>### So, the formula we are going to use is (n+1)/2 the solution to the question is 12.<n>### Next, we are going to place the original data in the provided equation.<n>

Suppose that the player to the left of Zach rolled an exactly 6 and as dictated by the rules of the game, Zach chose to swap a card in his hand and the card that was facing up on the table. He then lost the game. Now draw the probability that:<n> - This was the first time that the two cards had been swapped and the one card that was facing up lost and one of the cards facing down won.<n> - This was the second time that the two cards were swapped and the card facing down lost and the card facing up won.<n><n>```<n><n>### Instructon:A bag contains two green marbles, two red marbles, and four blue marbles. You pick out a marble, set it aside, and then pick another marble, without seeing either one. Write a program statement for a function that determines the probability that the set aside marble is:<n>  - A green marble<n>  - A red marble<n>  - Not a blue marble. <n><n>### Input<n>```<n>Input: A bag contains three green and two red marbles. You pull out a marble and keep it aside. A second marble is pulled out of the bag and it is neither red nor green. How many different outcomes are there for the first time you pull a marble out of the bag and have it not be either red or green?<n><n>```<n><n>```<n>Input: Mary has a pizza party and she gives each of her three guests exactly 1/4 of the pizza. She has 90 guests. How many 1/4 pizza slices does Mary have left?<n>```<n><n><n>```<n>Input : A man was on his way home for the evening and he sees a bus with a sign on
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Where do you put a new dining table? Choices:  A: cafeteria B: arranging papers C: in the park D: formal dining room E: house<n><n>### Response:		 C<n><n>### Input : What is the best way to learn more about other cultures?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Choices:1. Learn their traditions<n><n>### Input You can only check one box in this list. What kind of animal is the cutest to you? What is the rule for finding the remainder when dividing a number by 7?<n><n>### Answer: Multiply the divisor by the quotient to get the remainder.<n><n>### Question: Write two rules for finding the quotient of a division problem<n><n>Answer: Rule 1: Divide the dividend by the divisor<n>Rule 2: Substitute the dividend in the dividend/divisor

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Where would someone learn to play an upright piano? Choices:  A: music room B: music store C: music class D: medium E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Music Room<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The music room is found at school, and upright pianos are placed in music rooms where they are played during choir classses and lesson classes.<n><n>### Input; The cello is held upright so that the strings are parallel with the floor.<n><n>### Response;<n><n>Music Store<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>At a music store, there may be a cello that fits the description, but there is usually no one playing it where visitors can hear it.<n><n>###Input; An orchestra consists of four members; choose only the choices that are correct about an orchestra.<n><n>###Response;<n><n>The orchestra in the band room was rehearsing.<n><n>###Explanation:<n><n>Because an orchestra consists of different instruments, an orchestra can also be a class in which students learn about and play instruments.<n>The orchestra may be held in a band room, but there would not be sound or movement as in a typical performance.<n><n>###Input; The conductor of the orchestra stopped the students from playing.<n><n>###Recapition;<n>Conductors of orchestras conduct, or lead, groups of musicians. They are not generally in the orchestra that they lead.<n>The conductor of the orchester stopped all the students from playing. The music they were supposed to play made everything in the room stop.<n><n>###Answer Choices; The orchestra is a group of music enthusiasts who play a broad variety of instruments in a specific time.<n>The orchestra started playing again immediately.<n>

Choices:  A: stress B: food C: that you D: spending money E: walking<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Input<n>Input: How many stickers?<n>Output: ______<n><n>### Review:<n>In most instances, we'll need to store our input in a variable so that we can work with it. Let's begin with our variables.<n><n>### Let's store our Input:<n>In many of the programs we'll read the input using our Scanner class. By using Scanner, we can tell the computer what sort of input we want. Here's an example.<n><n>### We'll read the Input using Scanner:<n>In order for you to read input from the keyboard, you'll need to import the Scanner class. Here's a simple example where we read an integer from the user.<n><n>Now let's put this knowledge to work.<n><n>### How many stickers? <n><n>How many stickers?<n><n>56<n><n>What is the input? What is the output? What type of input are you entering? How much of an impact will the input have on the program’s functionality?<n>### Code:<n>        Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);<n>        System.out.println("How many stickers? ");<n>        String response = input.nextLine();<n>        int stickerCount = Integer.parseInt(response);<n>        System.println("In total you have " + stickerCount + " stickers.");<n>### Output<n>In total you have 56 stickers.<n>

Your age # years from now  = the square  of   age divided   by    the   square   of    one<n><n>### Response <n><n>The answer is B.<n><n>### How much does it cost to rent a car for 2 days?<n><n>Input:  Let the cost be x dollars.<n>Output:  x dollars.<n><n>Step1: 1<n>Step2: 2<n>Step3: x + 2 + 2 = 4 x<n>Step4: x = 4<n>######Step 5: 4 is the result of the problem.<n><n>### The cost for renting a car is $20. It takes $5 for a half day. The rent needs to be paid in one day. How much money will be paid total for a day?<n><n>Input: Let the cost be x.<n>Output: x.<n><n>Step1:(20/2) + (25/2) = 15 x<n>####Step2:x = 15<n>Step3:(20/2)*15+1 = 75 dollars.<n>Step4:(25/2)*15 +2 = 40 dollars.<n><n>### Two times three divided by two is equal to six.<n><n>### A number is greater than three and less than four.<n><n>### Six multiplied by five is greater than six.<n><n>## Exercise<n><n>### Input|Output<n><n>Input:<n><n>Output:<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### This is a fill-in-the blank question.<n><n>## Exact Solutions

What is the total sum of the following list of numbers from least to greatest? {1, 6, 0, 7, 1, 9, 4, 2, 10, 8, -2, 3}<n>A. What is 30 percent of a 30-minute radio show?<n>A. One-third of 100 is ____<n>A. If you add 6 and 7, multiply by three, take away 3, and divide by two, what is the end result?<n>A. The difference of 29 and 4 is ____<n><n>### Instuction:<n>Addition<n><n>### Demostration:<n>3 + 2 = ___<n>2 + 9 = __<n>__ =___<n><n><n>### Instraction: <n>Subtraction<n><n>### Demo:<n>24 - 12 = __<n><n>### Instrction:<n>Multiplication<n><n>### Demo1:<n><n>__ x 150 = __<n><n>## Instruction:<n>Division, multiply a number by __<n><n>## Demo:<n>94 ÷ 2 = __<n><n><n><n>## Instuction:<n>Multiply a number by __<n>And divide by __.<n><n>## Demo: <n><n>15 x 3 / ___ = __<n><n>## Demo2:<n>___ x 8 / 3 = __<n><n>## Answer: <n>___ x 8 ÷ 3 = 5<n><n>### Instution:<n>Multiply the greater number by __<n>And the smaller number by ___<n><n><n>## Demostration: <n>___ x ___ = ___<n><n>## Answer:<n>85 x __ = 7225<n><n>### Demo4:<n><n>__ x __ = 21976<n><n><n>## Instution:<n>A. Multiply by the greater number by ___<n>And the smaller one by ___. Example: 28 x 4 / 16 would be __ x __ = ___<n><n>B. Multiply by __ and divide by ___. Example: __ x 15 / 9 would be __ x __ / ___ = ___.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:An expressway can suffer from traffic, this traffic gets worse the closer you get to any what? Choices:  A: michigan B: map C: american city D: rest stops E: country<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n><n>### InputThe first day of December is 16 days away. How many days are between each date? How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. Choices:  A: communicating with others B: hurt feelings C: dry mouth D: intimacy E: changing behavior<n><n>### Response:		C,D<n><n>* **A** - If communication is to be effective it must be two way. The purpose of communication is to get understanding. Effective communication creates a win-win situation where both people walk away with a sense of feeling valued. We communicate to create connection.<n>* **B** - Effective communication will not work when individuals are not emotionally safe. It is important to learn to handle communication in order to not injure others emotionally. It can also be easy to hurt others because we don’t always have the skills to get our point on in clear, concise, and respectful ways. It is important to understand others perspectives and not put them on the defensive.<n>* **C** - I hate dry mouth, so I would focus on getting intimate. We will discuss feelings, thoughts and concerns. We will find solutions to problems. We will encourage one another. In short, we will create a safe place to bring our emotional issues to. Sometimes others cannot control their emotions. I can be very controlling, but a person who knows me can help to soften me. This will make me more receptive.<n>* **D** - I hope to build a better, more intimate relationship with the receiver.<n>* **E** - I want to help people change their feelings to better thoughts. I want to improve behavior by providing education and opportunity to change.<n><n>### Input 1: There are 53 people in the conference room. The conference room can fit 75 people. What is the maximum number of additional people that can fit in the room?<n><n>### Input<n>There are 53 people.<n><n>### Response<n>42<n><n>### Input2<n>What is the maximum number that the room can fit when 42 people are in the room and 35 are using the restroom?<n><n>### Answer<n>  42<n>  <n>### Input:<n>There are 45 people present at the party. However, we cannot include the birthday girl in our count because she is 3 times as old as the oldest person present. How many years is she?<n><n>### Response1:<n>It can be said that the number of years is (45 x 3). Then we would get the answer as x.<n><n>### The number of people who have been selected is 40. To

The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:If your watching television and accomplish nothing what have you done? How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:The man wanted to take a bus, but all the chars were full of people doing what? Choices:  A: sitting down B: refusing C: saving money D: sit down E: go outdoors<n><n>### Response:		<n>**D**
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Though nearby, an apple from an apple tree where would be an imported product to the USA? Choices:  A: ohio B: washington state C: alaska D: canada E: flowers<n><n>### Response:		<n>The closest answer is E, because the apples grow in a non-contiguous state such as Ohio.<n><n>### Input : A box is 26 inches long. A second box is 12 inches greater than 5 times A times B and 6 times C times D. Is C greater than 1 or less than 1?<n><n>### Response :<n>The greatest choice would be D, the most it could be smaller is 1.<n><n>### Question : You have 12 eggs, some of which are defective. You need a dozen of good eggs for baking. Find the least number of eggs that must be drawn.<n><n>### Response <n>Eggs 1,2... 12 can be good, the others could be broken<n><n>#### Solution: The least number of eggs that can be drawn to get the required number of good eggs, is 4 eggs.<n><n>### A: What is the lowest positive, non repeating decimal?<n><n>### B: If a negative number is added to a negative number, the result is ____________.<n><n>### C: There is a list of 6 non-negative numbers. One is repeated and one is missing but there are no duplicate numbers. What is the sum of this list?<n><n>### D: Add six positive integers. What is the sum?<n><n>### E: How many different ways can 7 people sit in 2 rows, with no more than 2 people in one row.<n><n>### Answer : Option B. To add a negative number to a negative number, you must subtract the negative one from the negative two. <n><n>### A) 0 B) -1 C) 2 D) 6 E) 2x as many as with 5 people +14 ways.<n><n>#### Solution:<n><n>We have six numbers in all, so each has a probability of occurring. Hence, there are a total of 6! ways in which the six numbers can be arranged.<n><n>6! = 6 × 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1 = 720<n><n>Hence the answer is <n>Option (C). There are only six different numbers, so the total number of ways in<n>which the six numbers can be grouped is 6!, which is 720<n>

Choices:  A: vomiting B: pleasure C: happiness D: contentment E: mess<n><n>### Response:		Contentment<n><n>### The Task:<n><n>1.  How many letters in the English alphabet are in alphabetical order?<n>2.  How many even numbers are in the set {2,5,10,17...}?<n>3.  How many distinct integers are to the left of 20, to the right of 20 and either straddle 20 or have 20 in the factorial?<n>4.  How many letters does it take to spell "crab"?<n>5.  Given a number n, how many of the letters of the Latin alphabet (a-z) can be formed using a, b,..., z and 0?<n>6.  How many three-digit numbers contain 3 in the units spot?<n>7.  How many letters are in the name DORIS?<n>8.  Given a number, how many distinct letters of the alphabet are in the factorial? <n>9.  How many ways can a pair of shoes be selected from among three pairs of shoes?<n>10.  How many 4-sided figures are there (such as squares, rectangles, triangles, diamonds, etc.)?<n>11.  How many times does one have to add 1 to get 10?<n>12.  How many letters begin the word "MATIN"?<n>13.  How many 1s are there in the factorial of 4?<n>14.  How many triangles are there in the shape ABCD?<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>The first line of the file contains t, the number of test input-test output problem pairs. The following t test input-test output pairs follow. Each problem pair consists of a description of a mathematical problem and a test input which is described after the initial number<n>1.  There are three different possible answers to this question.<n>2.  There are two different possible answers to this problem.<n><n>The input contains only the numbers from the set {1, 2,..., 20}. The input ends after a line containing only the end of input marker, which is a word containing no letters from the latin alphabet. The test input is then written on the following lines.<n>```

They all have a capital letter.  <n><n>## How will you show that this statement has a capital letter?<n><n>1. This statement has a capital letter to show it is true by defining what you want.<n>2. This statement has a _ _ _ _ _ _ to show it is true, but you have to figure that out.<n>3. This statement has a special kind of _ _ _ _ __.<n><n>### How will you prove that this statement has a special kind with _ _ _ _ _?<n><n>1. It is true because it doesn't make sense, but that is how you know.<n>2. This is not true; your answer is wrong.<n>3. This is not true at all.

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:For convenience some customers want things straight to the doorstep and use what? Choices:  A: mail orders B: demand satisfaction C: place money on counter D: pay merchants with money E: spend money<n><n>### Response:		Pay merchants.<n>

So, conditioning hearts is good (good means doing something to make it better).  So, A is correct answer.<n>### Input:B:  expend energy<n>### Response:Expend energy is also good (it means to use it well) <n>### Input:C:  laugh<n>### Response: Laughing is good (it means to be happy). How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:There's a lot to reproducing, but it begins and end with new life by giving what? Choices:  A: overpopulation B: birth C: presents D: propagation E: fun<n><n>### Response:		Birth<n><n>---<n><n>Copyright © 2020 Dice. All rights reserved.<n>

For doing so, banks usually charge a fee of $20. If there are no other costs, what is the most amount you can keep in your new account while keeping money in your current account of at least $25?<n><n>Answer:<n><n>60<n><n>###Instructions:The number shown above represents a series of numbers that were rotated by a number of places. The numbers are 0-9, each appearing one (1) time. You will be given the number of places the numbers were rotated. Rotate all series of numbers given a number of places to show their new arrangements.<n><n>###Instructon: Input: A rotated sequence had a sequence of 9 digits, 3 6 8 5 2 4 0 1 7, and a rotation count of 4. Output: A new sequence of 9 digits that is rotated 4 places.<n><n>###Response to instruction: For each series of 9-digits that has a rotatntion count of 4, I need to enter the new number that appears at the end of the rotation.<n><n>###Output: 952041368<n><n>###Instucton: Input: A sequence with 11 digits, a count of 3, and rotated the numbers 3. Output: The final sequence with a rotated count of 3.<n>###Response: Input: A sequence, with a rotated count, and a 2 place count. Output: The final number after the sequence is rotated and counted.<n><n>###Input: A: a sequence of 9, a rotation count of 1. Output: A 9 digit sequence that has been rotated with a count of 1.<n><n>###Comment: The order of the sequence in the inputs below is: 0123456789; I have created an if statement to check if the input is true or false.<n><n>###

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:The garage had light sensors and automatic doors, what kind of house was it? Choices:  A: modern house B: building C: townhouse D: neighbor's house E: downtown<n><n>### Response:		E<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Billy went away because his parents were fighting and he didn't want to stay where? Choices:  A: home team B: present C: at home D: come back E: charming<n><n>### Response:		C is correct<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following questions about the reading text.<n><n>A. How long does Billy's stay?<n><n>A. Four days. <n><n>B. Where does Billy have to stay? <n><n>B. Charlie's house. <n><n>C. Why does Billy go away?<n><n>C. Because his parents were fighting. <n><n>D. Is there a special gift for Charlie?<n><n>D. Yes, he has brought his cat. <n><n>### Instuctions:Write a sentence from the story.<n><n>I went to the movie with my friends today.<n><n>### Input:{ "student":[ "John", "I", "Went", "To", "The", "Movie", "With", "My", "Friends", "Today." ] }<n><n>### Response:[ "John", "I went to the movie today with my friends"]  <n><n>### Instxtions:Write a response to this. 5 words or more.<n><n>I don't like this one so I'm not going to eat it.<n><n>### Response:{ "Student": [ "I", "am", "not", "going", "To", "Eat", "This"] }<n><n>### Input:[ "John", "do", "not", "like", "eating", "fruits" ]<n><n>### Response:"I don't like eating fruits"<n><n>### Instutckions:Write a response below to this.<n><n>I made a pizza.<n><n>### Write a response below to this:<n><n>We watched the movie yesterday.<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Where do most people keep magazines? Choices:  A: bookstore B: library C: doctor D: home E: table<n><n>### Response:		<n>A B E<n><n>### Note:<n>The correct answer is A.<n><n>### Input<n>How many cigarettes does a person smoke per hour of working? Choices: 1. 3 times more than per day 2. 7.5% more per minute 3. 3 times less than per minute 4. 7.5 times less than per hour<n><n>### Response<n>1 A<n><n>### Note<n>The correct answer is 3.<n><n>### Note <n>The explanation is given at http://mathwithbabysteps.com/2017/04/04/how-to-guess-the-missing-quantity-in-the-riddle/. Read this to get an idea of how my brain comes up at these questions.<n><n>### Question<n>Write a program that reads the word of the day and prints how it's used in the sentence.<n>The file contains a sentence and another line with the word of the day.<n>**Input**<n>The sentences.<n>**Output** The program that prints how the sentence is used in the word of the day in the sentence.<n><n>**Input**<n>Jen is my teacher.<n>The word of the day is friend.<n><n>**Output**<n>friend <n>Jen is my friend<n><n>**Note**<n>The program should not print friend or  friend.<n><n>### Questions<n>What other data set do you wish to work on?<n><n><n># [Solution]: <n>## Write a program that reads the sentence into a string.<n>## Then tokenize it to create a sentence as a set of simple sentences.<n>## Each simple sentence will be its own sentence with a word separator.<n>## Then, store the words of each sentence in separate variables, each set in a list.<n>## Then, find the word in the word of the sentence.<n>## If the current word is inside of the word of the day, print the sentence and that word.<n>## Else, go to the next step of the loop.<n>## The first function in the function takes the input of the list of words in the sentence and the word of the day as inputs.  The function takes the first argument and searches for it in the second argument.  It returns the position of how it found it.  If it doesn't find it, it returns -1.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:How can buildings like the Empire State building be described? His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:A person writes a check to a clerk, where does the clerk put them? Choices:  A: cash register B: desk drawer C: pay envelope D: throw away E: box<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Conventions:<n>There are 4 choices total:<n><n>- D: throw away<n>- A: cash register<n>- B: desk drawe<n>- C: pay envelope<n><n>### Conclusions:<n>The response given is D: throw away, which is the correct answer.<n>

Choices:  A: supermarket B: motel C: at hotel D: shampoo bottle E: hair salon<n><n>### Response:		<n>The option is A, the supermarket<n><n>## 57. A word problem is given. Write a response that demonstrates your ability to solve the problem.<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>## 58. Read the word problem and the steps how to solve it.  Answer the question.<n><n>## Solution<n>>I have 5 friends<n>>3 more than my friend Jenny<n>>8 more than Jesse and Rachel<n>>7 more than Matt<n>>How many<n><n>Sarah, Jenny, Jesse, Rachel, and Matt are my friends and I like having a birthday party every year. Everyone knows that and we all agree on a location for the party that Sarah picks every year. This year, 4 friends will go to a new location of my party and the remaining two will visit someone nearby. There won’t be much confusion as all my friends know that my birthday party location is a common theme that we choose.  Sarah will also choose what activity we do at the location.<n><n>The 4 friends who visit a new location will visit a beach destination that Sarah picks. Matt will be able to have his family come while the other three friends will visit somewhere near their residence.  When Matt has his family at his house, my friends won’t need to visit his house because Matt has a big residence.<n><n>With Matt at the location, my friends can have some fun. Jenny, Jesse and Rachel plan to go to the beach. As of now, 14 friends will be at my birthday party this year. 7 of the 14 people are my friends who will be at Matt’s place. As of now, 7 of the 8 people that visit their nearby location are all my friends except my sister. The remaining three friends I will visit their house.<n><n>As of now, there are 4 of my friends who visit with me another 7 others who are not my friends. So 3 of my friends are not at my party this year by choosing to stay at their nearby location.<n><n>The solution is 4<n>

They had went through a lot and so far they had not gone out.  He felt that they needed to move to the next step, but he was scared that it was going to ruin his relationship with her.  He didn't want to take her out.  It was that he didn't want this to ruin his relationship either.<n><n>### Response<n>James needed to realize that continuing this process of trying to make Jen feel more comfortable is the best and the only possible answer.  He decided to stay with the process by continuing.<n>

Ferret has cats and rats. Fox has doves and rabbits. A cat and a dove has the same number of legs. A rat and a dove has the samme number of legs. A rabbit and a cat has the samme number legs. What animal has the most legs out of the pets Ferret and Fox have?<n><n>### Instuctions:Answer the question by including all details.<n><n>### Question:If the total number of legs that Ferret and Fox have is 60, how many kittens does Ferret have?<n>   <n>### Instruction for Expert:15 marks<n>```<n>The best way to get to the answer is to create a simple program with the data.<n>In the program ask user to feed in the values (if the number of legs is too many or for example a negative one, then the program should halt)<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: see king B: hello C: meow D: drink water E: live many years<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>* Choices: - meow<n><n>### Input - A: what would you normally expect ____________________?<n><n>### Response - E: live many years
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Where will a native lemur be found? Choices:  A: india B: hole C: cage D: habitat E: rain forest<n><n>### Response:		Choice: E: rain forest<n>

Choices:  A: idaho B: casserole C: new hampshire D: root cellar E: ireland<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Demostration:<n>We see from the question that, as I am writing my answer, that I see, there are 50 children, 3/5 of them are boys.<n><n>So, when I solve the problem, I get the number of the girls: 20.<n><n>### Input:(Father and daughter are having a conversation.)<n>“Dad, I found this piece of paper that tells me how much your allowance was. It was $250. Now I know why I had so much fun.”<n><n>How much allowance did the daughter actually get?<n><n>### Response:(Answer)<n>$175<n><n>### Demosntration:<n>My father used to tell me that when he was my age, he would earn $175 dollars a month. However, I didn't really know how he was able to do that, since it is rare that any teenager at my school makes that kind of money from working.<n><n>Now that I found that piece of paper, I can compare his allowance to mine and see that his allowance was indeed $175 more than my own allowance - the father is telling the truth. This makes me think perhaps it was not something that was special to his situation or a time, but maybe something that was just the norm. I wonder what my allowance will be next week.<n><n>### Suggestion:Consider adding an introduction.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Where is a monkey likely to be found in the rainforest? Choices:  A: tree tops B: rain forest C: zoological gardens D: great outdoors E: zoo<n><n>### Response:		A<n>

They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. Choices:  A: footloose B: sailing C: fast D: tighten E: bind<n><n>### Response:		A.B. C.D. E.<n><n>### Input :There were a total of of 700 men in the army. Of them, how many didn’t pass their test? Options: A. 16 B. 33 C. 50 D. 64 E. 100<n><n>### Response :C<n><n><n>    int count = 0;<n>    for (int i = 0; i < 700; i++)<n>    {<n>        if (i % 2!= 0)<n>        {<n>            count++;<n>        }<n>    }<n>      if (count == 0)<n>      {<n>        Console.WriteLine("Everyone passed their test!");<n>      }<n>      else<n>      {<n>        // You may output every person that didn't pass.<n>        Console.WriteLine($"Total that didn't pas their test: {count}");<n>      }<n>        Console.ReadKey();<n><n>### Instuction:How many people were there at the party?<n><n>### Instructions:How many children are there in the school?<n><n>### <n><n>### Input:"Fred was 1/7 times as tall as his sister and 1/6 times as old as Mary." If Fred is 30 years old and his sister is 12 years old, what is Mary's age?<n><n>### Input:(10% > 5%) => true => 10 > 5<n><n>     static void Main(string[] args)<n>     {<n>        int age = 10;<n>        int numDays = 100;<n>    <n>        string percentage = "%";<n>    <n>        boolean pass = 0;<n>    <n>        <n>        switch (percentage)<n>        {<n>        case "% == " + "*10% >= *5%":<n>            Console.WriteLine("Yes, the percentage is at least 10% (passed).");<n>            pass = true;<n>            break;<n>        <n>        case "% ==  " + "*5% < *-1%":<n>            Console.WriteLine("No 10% < 5% (passed)." );<n>        break;<n>        <n>         default:<n>            Console.WriteLine( "The percentage is not equal to those given (failed)."

Choices:  A: envy B: resentment C: winning or losing D: one winner E: two winners<n><n>### Response:		 <n><n>### Instructions:Fill in the blanks to demonstrate the following process. <n><n>### Input 1<n><n>```<n>[ ] if (someCondition)<n>{<n>	[  ]  someStatement;<n><n>    }<n>    else<n>	{<n><n>    [ ]  someOtherStatement;<n>    [ ] anotherMethod();<n>    [ ] someAnotherStatement;<n><n><n>}<n>```<n><n>### Response<n><n>When the expression `someCondition` is false, run the function `else` and then run another function, `anotherMethod`. If the statement `else` evaluates to `true`, run the function `else`. Otherwise, in `else` run the function `else`, and then run another function `someOtherStatement`.<n>

If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:What is a place where you usually store dishes but not books? Choices:  A: apartment B: pantry C: table D: living room E: shelf<n><n>### Response:		Living room<n><n>### Input:"How much money do you earn each month?"<n><n>### Response:"I earn £300 every month."<n><n>### Input:(140-28)*3)=480<n><n>### Output:140*3-40-28=480<n><n>

One fourth are girls, the rest are boys.  How many boys are there in my class?<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>What: G<n><n>Where: B<n><n>Why: My answer is going to be one fourth is going to be 12+ the rest is 36 that means there is 49 boys.<n><n>### Problem<n><n>The following lines of code are incorrect.<n>-   You are attempting to access an element before that element is added to the DOM.<n>-   The `onClick` event fires before the element is added to the page, but is attached to a reference to an element that does not yet exist.<n><n>The following line attempts to access a reference to an element before that element exists in the DOM.<n>-  `console.log(document.getElementsByName('studentAname'));`<n><n>### Solution<n><n>The following line of code will resolve the problem as it will find elements with the `studentAname` text that's added to the DOM. You can attach the listener to the newly created elements.<n>    <n>    const studentNameRefs = document.getElementsByName('studentName');<n>    studentNameRefs.onclick((name) => {<n>        let nameValue = name.value;<n>    })<n><n><n>### Write A Code to perform the following task. <n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>The following lines are incorrect. <n>The `querySelector()` method is not available. <n>It is defined in the `document` object.<n>```<n>const studentNameRefs = <html document >.querySelector ('.studentAname');<n>```<n><n>The following line will find the names in the student table in html. <n>You can attach
