How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:The family was playing cards, what would be a reason for this? Choices:  A: amusement B: losing money C: charmed D: having fun E: win money<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Input A: A boy has a pet snake. Choices:   D: a rabbit   B: a dog   B: a cat   C: a wolf   E: a ferret <n><n>### Response A: B<n><n>### Input B: A man bought a car. Choices:   C: gave away the car   A: destroyed the car   B: sold the car  D: lost the car E: destroyed the car<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:The woman experienced great joy, but despite that this was a what? Choices:  A: misery B: sadness C: bad time D: sorrow E: play time<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: misery<n><n>### Instructions:<n>1.  What is the rule?<n>1.  How do you solve this problem?<n>1.  When is it possible?<n>1.  Draw a picture if its helpful<n>1.  Give examples if they help<n>1.  Make sure you describe all the steps.<n>1.  Be clear, complete, and accurate.<n>1.  It MUST be true!<n>1.  Be specific and avoid being vague.<n><n>## #Exercise<n><n>### Instructio:<n>* What's the rule?<n>* How do you solve it?<n>* When is it possible? ___________________<n>* Draw a picture if it helps you.<n>* Give examples if they help.<n>* Make sure you describe all your steps.<n>* Be clear, complete and accurate.<n>

If 6 in every nine students are taller than 62 inches tall, which of the following groups of students does NOT necessarily have to be tested to determine which is the tallest student in the school? <n><n>### Choice 1:<n><n>1- All students who are only a little taller than 6'2.<n><n>2- All students in the entire 6'2 - 6'9 region of the graph.<n><n>3- The 42 students who are taller than 50”.<n><n>4-The 30 students who are shorter than 52".<n><n>Answer 3: All students taller than 52’ would need to be tested to know which one is the tallest student.<n><n>### Answer 2 Input The average score on the exam was 90, and 40% of the students got a perfect 100. What score, rounded to the nearest ten, must every student get to bring the average up to 91?<n><n>### Choices 1 and 2 were correct and Choice 3 were wrong.<n><n>### Answers 3 Input There are four shelves in a grocery store. Shelf #1 has 30 gallons of milk and 224 cans of beans. Shelf 2 has 94 gallons of milk and no beans. Shelf #3 has 451 cans of beans 60 less gallons than beans on Shelf #1 and 30 more gallons of milk than milk on Shelf #4. Shelf #4 has 59 gallons of milk and has 264 cans of beets. How many cans of beans are in each grocery store?<n><n>### Answer Choice 3 Input A company hired an employee and gave him a laptop to work with. He will work from home twice a month on those days. Choices:  A: feel proud B: try to learn C: need assistance D: thank god E: read alot<n><n>### Response:		If I want to get good grades I will feel proud of myself when the teacher tells me they are impressed with my papers. Also, I have to try really hard to learn every thing that is in the book. I don't know what I would do if I wanted to get good grates, but I think a person would need a lot of help to learn things he or she doesn't know how too. I don't think a person would have to thank god because if a person try hard and really work to get good grades they will be able to get good grades. I don't really know if I would read alot if I wanted to get better grades because I don't like to read that much. I probably wouldn't worry I'd try and get better. If you want good grades you have to feel proud about yourself because if your teacher tells you good job you could feel proud if you don't think you did so good and you try hard every day maybe your teachers will tell you good job.<n>

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. Choices:  A: mountain dew B: glass C: soft drink D: whirlpool bath E: coffee cup<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>##### Validation<n><n>- What is the original text?<n><n>- What is your response to the task?<n><n>- Is it correct or not?<n><n>##### Why did you post your own response?<n><n>- You did not like another student's solution.<n>- Your response is better than it was before.<n>- The teacher did not understand your solution.<n>- The solution needs to be checked.<n>- You are trying to improve your own skill with the language.<n><n>### Your Turn<n><n>Write a response where you make improvements to your previous responses.<n><n>### Challenge<n><n>- Challenge yourself with a harder/more difficult response.<n>- Challenge someone else to make improvements to their work.<n><n>### Goals<n><n>##### Your goals.<n><n>##### Other goals.<n><n><n>### Further Practice<n><n>Write a response to the task below. <n><n>### Task:<n><n>Input: <n><n>Megan is the youngest of three sisters. Choices: A: price tag B: brand name C: speed gauge D: warranty E: lightning protection<n><n>### Input : If a book weighs 3/4 lb, how heavy will it be with the dust jacket (if it has one)?<n><n>**Input:** [3555/4976]<n>**Response:** One of the options is correct.<n><n>If a book weighs [3555 lb] with the dust jacket, it would weigh around [3555] lb.<n><n>```ruby<n>puts "Please enter the weight of the book without the dust jacket.".to_s<n><n>puts "Please type the weight with the dust jacket"<n><n>#get the value of the weight with dust jacket<n>value =$stdin.gets.chomp.to_f<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>**I want to buy a T-shirt. The T-shirt says, “I was in the ’90s!”  On one wall, the T-shirt says 1989-97, and I think it might be a U.S. tour T-shirt.  I need to sell this T-shirt for at least $20.  The other shirts are all in similar good condition as mine except the ’90s t-shirt.  How much would I be able to sell it for?  <n>**Input:** 125 <n>**Response:** <n><n>The T-shirt says ’90s, which means the shirt is worn between 1980 to 2000, this means it was a US tour. <n><n>Let’s say I bought this T-shirt from a store for $30 in the range of the year 1980-2000.<n><n>Assuming the store price is $32, I can sell it for at least $50, since everyone is in the ’90 for $20,<n><n>My T-shirt is worn from 1980 which means its quality is excellent for $52/year,  which is $96/

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:The people wanted to take the scenic route, they chose the highway that cut through the what? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Where can you get a stray small dog? Choices:  A: living room B: animal shelter C: georgia D: pet shop E: dog show<n><n>### Response:		B.<n><n>### Input:#723 and 20 <n><n>### Input:"I have (734 -56) apples and I want (787- 153) apples. Choices:  A: football stadium B: surface of earth C: car show D: opera E: movie<n><n>### Response:		The first and the third options both contain moving objects.  I will go with C as it has the most objects.<n><n>In the first option, what people look at moves.  What people look at is football players. In opera players move around on stage but it is not moving within stadium.<n><n>In the third option, there are movable objects (moving cars)<n><n>### InputA:The first and the second options are similar in having moving objects. <n><n>### ResponseA:The only difference will be in the people attending each option.<n><n>A would be a sports match and it has the spectators.  <n><n>B would be for a game where people are playing football. We see the people as spectators in B and we see the game as a player.  There are no spectators in a game when we are playing.<n><n>### InputB:In the first option, the things are similar where as in the second option, the things are different.<n><n>### ResponseB:<n><n>In the first options the spectators are similar. (in sports they look at things)<n><n>In the second option, the moving thing is different. (playing football)<n><n>### InstructionsB:<n><n>Write the words for each group and list them on the second tab under 'The Same'.<n><n><n>### OutputA:<n>    Same<n>    Football game<n><n>### OutputB:<n>    Different<n>    Football game<n>     <n>### InputC:<n><n>### ResponseC:<n><n>## InputD:<n><n><br><n><n><table><n>	<tr><n>	  <td>First Option</td><n>	  <br><n>	  <table><n>	  <tr><n>	 	<td>People (Looking At)</td><n>		<td>Football Players (Looking At Them)</td><n> 	  </tr><n>	  </table><n>	</tr><n>	<tr><td>Second Option</tr></td><n>	<br><n>	<table><n>	 	<n>	 	<tr><n>     		<td>Peoples (Looking At) In Car Show</td><n>	      <td>Cars (Looking At Themselves)</td><n>

If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:What creatures performing pollination are loved my millions? Choices:  A: birds B: action C: butterflies D: happiness E: anxiety<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question as follows.<n><n>### Input<n>Input: Mary had stickers.  She put 4 to the front of her journal and 8 to the back. She also used 4 on 2 other pages. How many stickers did she use in all?<n>Answer: 80<n><n>Input(Answer to above problem): Alex’s mom gave him $30 to go to the mall to buy a new shirt. He wanted to spend more than that, so he took out a loan of $10 from his grandparents. At the mall, Alex bought a shirt for $50 and a pair of socks for $15. Alex borrowed an extra $3 from his best friend and he still had $6 left. What is the total money Alex had at the mall?<n>Answer: He had a total of $58<n><n>Input: Jenna has 3 times as many dolls as toys and 4 times as many toys as stuffed animals. She has $5 in total to spend. How much can she spend on each?<n>Answer: Jenna has the option to spend at least $0.75 on dolls, stuffed animals or toys.<n><n>Input: There was a party.  There are three more girls who than boys.  How many more girls than boys?<n>Answer: Girls: 3 more<n><n>Input: The sum of the digits of a seven digit number is 21. What is the number?<n>Answer: 909<n><n>Input: There’s a number with three 6’s. Subtract 9 from the number. The answer is greater than half the number. What is the number<n>Answer: 508<n><n>Input: If 17 and 18 are written as A and B and the product of 17 and 21 is A, then what is the value of 1<n><n>Answer: A X B = AB 17 X 21 = 17 + 21 = 38<n><n>AB = 38<n>A X B = 38<n>13 B = 38 - 13 = 121<n>B = 121 ___<n>X = A + 13<n><n>17<n><n>X = 24

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Deciding to watch tv or play with your cell phone might be a routine but they provide no help in being able to do what? Choices:  A: order B: queueing up C: wait turn D: fatigue E: anger<n><n>### Response:		Order line and stand in line are synonyms, hence we should only choose A.<n><n>### Input:"I haven't seen Mia and Sam play that song at the same time." Is this similar to:<n>"Mary's aunt's birthday is in September."<n>Choice:<n>1 Choices A and E are similar as they both have an implicit subordinate clause "that song".<n>2 Choices A and B are similar as they both don't have an implicit subordinate clauses.<n>3 Choices C and A are similar as they both use the prepositional phrase "at the same time" to create an implicit subordinate clause.<n>4 Choices D and B are similar as both of them don't have an implied noun to give context to the subject.<n>5 Choices A and E contain similar structure of the sentences as they both have the predicate verb "is" which makes them similar.<n><n>### Response:"I haven't seem Mia and Sam play the song at the same time".(A and E) Are both grammatically correct.<n><n>--------------------------------------------------------------------------------<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>#### Instructions:<n>Write a function named `reverseString()` with the statement signature as follows:<n><n>`reverseString(str)`<n><n>#### Demonstration:Write a `reverseString()` function that can reverse the string `str`:<n><n>`reverseString('helloworld')`<n>`should return 'dlrowolleh'`<n><n>#### Instrucions:The length of the input string `str` will be 25<13, 25>13.<n><n>#### Response:<n><img alt="image" src="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/27929988/93967622-1951c180-f564-11eb-8076-6b3cb2867e81.png" height="234"><img alt="image" height="232" src="https://raw.githubusercontent. com/lumoid-public/lumoid-frontend/gh-pages/img/reverse.png"><n>

It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Where can I find a steakhouse with a view of corn fields? Choices:  A: nebraska B: new york C: mexico D: home E: utah<n><n>### Response:		New York<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Everybody seemed to have a horse not just the regular gamblers, which event always brings out the biggest crowds to the sport? How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5. If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. I put it in my office.<n><n>### Input I wanted  a side chair but one that could fold away neatly when not in use, where did I find it? Choices: A: kitchen B: closet C: table D: hallway E: bathroom<n><n>### Response The closet is where I found the side chair.It could fold away neat but I had it where I could pull it out to use.<n><n>### Question<n>Given a string, return the number of leading spaces in any word instance in the string.<n><n>For example, in "the     quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog", the leading spaces in the word instances are "the", "quick", "brown", and "jumped", so your function should return 13.<n><n>### Hint: There are no leading spaces in the substring "over the lazy dog."<n><n>### Challenge<n>The leading spaces in your question's input string are 15, not 13. Use the input from my challenge to make a function that returns the correct answer.<n><n>### Solution<n>The leading spaces in "the quick brown fox...' answer was the wrong one.Use these ideas to write the solution.<n><n>Input:string=the quick brown fox jump over the lean dog<n>Output:leading spaces=15<n><n>Input:leading spaces=16<n>Output:the quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog<n><n>### Output:<n>Return the number of leading spaces, not the number of spaces between words (you could do that later if you chose).<n><n>There are no leading spaces in "" since the empty string has 0 leading spaces.<n><n>Input:<n>string=<n><n>Output:<n>0<n>

Choices:  A: greedy B: worry C: have knowledge D: take charge E: boss<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>#### Explanation:<n><n>* C<n><n>### Input<n>> John wanted to see the latest play at the theater.  He wanted to take his friend with him.  He told his friend, "One seat on the first row costs 10 dollars, two seats on the second row cost 15 dollars, and three seats on the third row cost 20 dollars.  How much do all 4 seats on the third row together cost?"  John's friend replied, "216 dollars".  How many seat on the third row does John's friend have to cover his share for the tickets?<n><n>#### Explanations:<n><n>* A seat in the first row is _____.<n><n>* A seat on the second row is _____. <n><n>* A seat within the third row is _____.  <n><n>#### Explanaton of the question: <n><n>In the first row, you have 6 seats. For each row you add at least one seat. In the 2nd row you have 4 seats. For every row you have an extra seat. The 3rd row has 3 seats. Now you need to add an extra seat to cover every row. After adding an extra seat for each row from the first to the forth you will get 1 seat in the fifth row.<n><n>### Input 2<n>>John and his friend, Mary, are doing a favor for Aunt Clara.  There are total amount of 29 pairs of socks.  Twenty four of them must be pairs of black socks and 5 must be pairs of blue socks.  All of them need to be given away. How many pairs of socks will need to be given away?<n>#### Explanation<n>This task is an "and" problem. I have given you the different types of socks. So, to do this task, I must be careful and I must remember to select everything, which is needed. In the first sentence, I said 24 pairs of black, this means every pair will be selected from the first part of the options. Also, I selected blue for the other five. I would rather pick the other 20 pairs first before selecting which five will be blue.<n><n>### Task 1 input<n>>The teacher had 30 students who had to sit in 7 rows with 4 students in each row

Choices:  A: loss of consciousness B: relaxation C: snoring D: dreaming E: talking<n><n>### Response:		(A,B,C,D,E)<n>### Instruction<n>* In each question, there are four answers, only one of which is correct, and you need to find that correct answer in the questions.<n>* Each answer is only correct only one question so your response to the questions has to be specific about the answer in the question it applies to.<n>* Your response has to answer all the questions, the more questions you answer, the more points.<n> <n>Input: There are exactly 986,000 milliliters of water in a river.  A farmer needs to water his vegetable garden twice as much as that for each day for 4 weeks. What is the minimum number of days he needs to spend watering his garden?<n>Answer: 58<n><n>**Input:** There are exactly 996,060 milliliters in a river. A farmer needs to use double this volume for 4 months. For how long must the farmer use the water?<n>**Answer:** 1992 * 4 = 7964 * 3 * 2<n><n>Input: Every time John buys a new car he is offered to insurance. If an insurance policy has $200 premium for the first year and $300 for each additional year and if he pays the same premium all these years, how much does John pay annually on car insance?<n>**Answer: 300*(4 - 1)**<n><n>Input: A bag contains 10 coins that are either 1 cent, 5 cent, 1 dollar or 5 dollar. There are only four different combination of coins as a result a bag can have if pick 7 coins without replacement. What is the probability of picking five fives?<n>**Answer:****5! / (10!-5!-1!-5!-3!)*****0.75**<n><n>Input: There were 36 hours at a certain time. 7 boys needed 9 minutes of sleep. How many minutes were left before the boys woke up?<n>**Answer: (24-9)*180/360**<n><n>Input: When there is 120 degrees, the wind speed is 7 km per hour. The wind blows 18

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:What is the opposite of a village? Choices:  A: rural area B: africa C: ohio D: big city E: tribe<n><n>### Response:		I answered D. As I looked through the answer choices, I found a little confusion on what the term village meant to the question giver.  I found that many of the terms in the answers were related to the term village, so I had to make sure I understood what the term village meant.  I answered D because I have attended both a large city convention and a village, so to me the two sounded quite different.  I hope my answer was correct!<n><n>### Input<n>Give me 9. What is 9x7<n><n>### Response<n>I answered 63. I used the same method used in the question from above.  I subtracted 6 from 9 to end up with -3.  I multiplied 3 times 7.  I ended up with 21.  I subtracted my answer from 9 and my answer was 7.<n><n>### Input.<n>The population goes from 250 to 300 every year. How many years?<n><n>### Response.<n>I answered 3.  I used the simple strategy of subtracting a large number and a small number.  In this question, 300 was a lot larger than 250, so I know 300 is going to be larger than 255.  Therefore, I can subtract larger numbers, 300 and 250, to end up with a solution of 50.  The solution is 50 and there are two solutions.  In the first 50, the population stays the same.  In the second 50, the number of people increases.  There are two solutions to this question as well, 50 + 250 = 300 and -50 + 200 = 30.  I answered 3 because this was the smallest solution, which is the answer I received.<n><n>### INPUT.<n><n>Hal, Dylan, and Nate divide a pie into 3 even pieces. How much did each kid get?<n><n>### RESPONSE<n><n>I answered by subtraction, which I did in another task.  I saw that you could subtract 2 or 3 times something to arrive at 0.  This worked for every problem.  Nate = 0 for every possible choice.  Hal =0

He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:What would someone wear to protect themselves from a cannon? Choices:  A: ungulate B: bomber C: body armor D: tank E: hat<n><n>### Response:		A, in cannon you can't use this because the cannon is stronger than the gun, but you need to protect your body if you use this you will be strongest.<n><n><n>### Input 2: A pig can run 1.5 miles in 1 minute and 37 seconds. What is the average speed of a pig running a mile?<n><n>### Response 2:1.5÷1.5+7 seconds because it takes 1.5 seconds to go.15 + the 7 minutes to go one mile<n><n><n>### Instructions 3:<n><n>### Description:<n><n><n>Input: The ratio of cows to pigs in a pen is 3:4. If a total of 58 piglets are born in the pen, how many pigs are born?<n>Answer: 8<n><n>Input: A group of bikers is taking a trip. The rider has an average speed of 36 miles/hour. If the trip was 305 miles long, how long did it take the group to bike?<n>Answer 2: 5<n><n>Input: 47 books are on the shelf in the library. Each shelf is split equally between science fiction and fantasy books. Half of the fantasy books are written by women. One female author wrote 800 books. What percentage of the library is filled with fiction?<n>Answer<n><n>#### Input5:<n><n>Input: In a group of 9 baseball players, there is a boy. What is the fraction of players that are boys?<n>Answer:1/9<n><n>Input: There were 5 more boys than girls at the party. How many more boys than girls were at the party?<n>Answer:7<n>

If the total prise of the meal comes tot sixty seven and they have a coupornt of for four how much does eacrhyi person need to <n>contributed to the bill?<n><n>To find the money owed to the coupon from the total price of meal, we need to subtract the couprn from the total price of the bill that is $67 - $4= $63.<n><n>Their bill is $63.  Each person needs to contributed $16.75.<n><n>Answer: $63 - $4 = $63; $63 / 3 = $21; $21 * *3 = $63.

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Why would I want to be exercising? Choices:  A: fatigue B: relaxation C: tiredness D: muscle weakness E: losing weight<n><n>### Response:		<n>```text<n>A. fatigue: Fatigue is a state of physical or mental strength or ability resulting from bodily or mental exertion, illness, or stress.<n>Ex. (He is always exhausted after a long day at work.)<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>You have been given $6.80 to buy groceries.  Use the information below to answer the following questions.<n>* You have ten items to purchase.<n>* Everything costs $1.  You will take cash.<n>* All four items cost $0.25 each.<n>* You cannot purchase any of the 10 items for free.<n>* 8-ounce cartons of milk and 16-ounce jugs of milk cost $3 for each size.<n>* Eight-ounce cans of peaches are $0.25.<n>* One-pound containers of orange juice are $0.50.<n>* Sixteen-ounce containers of apples are $1 and fourteen-ounce containers of pears are $0.30.<n>* Two-pound bags of sugar are $0.58.<n>* Eleven-ounce jars of peanut butter are $0.79.<n>How much money do you have left to spend on other items?<n>How many eight-ounce containers of peaches can you purchase?<n>How many fourteen-ounce containers can you purchase?<n>Select all of the items that you can buy?<n><n>### Response<n>```text<n>10x0.25=0.25 -> 25cts left with 6.80->0.25+0.25+......0.25/0.25=10<n>0.25+16(50c) =15. 15/3=5<n>3 items can fit in 6.80<n>```<n><n>* 0.58*2=1.16 ->$1.28<n>* 0.79*11=8.59 ->$10.59<n>```text<n>0.25*4 ->9cts<n>0.25<n>0.25(6) ->75cts<n>1.16(6) <n>17<n><n>0.25 can'

Choices:  A: pond B: underwater C: aquarium D: lake superior E: body of water<n><n>### Response:		B Lake Superior is an ice covered lake.<n>### Input:Today, you will participate in an activity which involves solving 32 problems.  You will get a bonus worth 20% more than the sum of all that you answer correctly.  The bonus is always positive and will never be less than the sum of all the solutions you answer.  Every problem has the following form: you are given a number, followed immediately by another number:  x + 3 = 13  What is the first number? You know that each individual problem has its own answer, never seen before.  All of the answers come from the number 1 to 20. How many bonus points should you earn for getting each of the 32 problems right?<n>### Response:The bonus is 20% of the sum of all the given problems. So to solve this you would need to answer 32/32 which is equal to 1.<n>### Input:[16, 23, 31, 40, 49, 58] + 2 + 5 + 5 + 8 + 7 + 3 = 87. A: The sum of numbers from 1 to 21  B: The sum of numbers 1 to 10<n>### Response:Let's start with the first number that is 16. If we subtract 16 from 87 we get 71. This would make the second set of numbers be the sum of numbers from 7 to 23. This answer is correct.<n><n>### Input:[3, 6, 15, 33, 65, 25,110, 79] + 7 = 757. A: The product of the first 8 numbers from 1 to infinity (inclusive)  B: The sum to 110  C:The sum of the even numbers <n>### Response:  The even numbers sum to 140 and so does the sum of numbers from to 110 but with the even numbers we are looking at every even number. So it would be C.<n><n>### [27, 23,35, 27, 87, 35, 4, 39, 29

Choices:  A: bathroom B: house C: cupboard D: space shuttle E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		<n>If one cannot detect any source of the smell, then the next likely location for smell is either from the bathroom or from the kitchen. If the problematic source is the kitchen, the user is required to remove it or seek help to replace it. The user must remove all non-essential items to check if the smell is from the item such as dish detergent.<n><n>### Input - How many animals does it take to open 500 lids? Choices: 0 A: 5 B: 10 C: 20 D: 50 E: 150 F: 500<n><n>### Response - 5<n><n>### Input There are 12 boys in the boys' dorm and a total of 15 girls. How many more girls does it take to make a perfect ratio? <n><n>### Response 3<n><n>### Input Max needs to buy 84 candy bars for a party. Each store has a 50% off of the candy bar sale. Store B's sale is only half of the cost. He can only go to one store. <n><n>### Choices: <n><n>* 2<n>* 3<n>* 19<n>* 29<n>* 32<n><n>### Response Choices: 2 or 3<n><n>## Extra Credit Challenges<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a program using a loop. Choices:  A: eat grass B: play C: kept in stables D: dominated E: drink coffee<n><n>### Response:		 B<n><n>### Instructions:<n>The task involves a statement with at most five possible responses.  There is one and only one correct response.  Write a python program that, given a string statement from the task, evaluates the statement and print the string with a letter at each index location indicating whether the substring at that index location is the correct response or not.<n><n>### Note:<n><n>* The task is expected to have a statement of 5 or less answers.<n>* An "empty" answer should not generate any output.  If no answers are correct then all letters should be blank.<n>* If there are 6 responses in the task then both the "empty" and all the incorrect responses should be blank.<n><n>### Example #1:<n><n>Input: A: What do horses do to get some energy? B: eat grass C: play D: kept in stables E: drink coffee<n>Output: A: false<n><n>### Example - #2:<n><n>Input: C: 3 divided by 5 equals? D: 6 E: 1 F: 3 G: 45<n>Output: C: 3 D: 3 E: 3 F: false G: false<n><n>## 2.0 - Hints<n>### Solution: Code Slicing<n>* Each case of the multi choice task should not get more than 30 lines. <n><n>### Problem: Incorrect Response<n>If the substring matches the input case but it is not the correct response then print BLANK<n>### Example: <n>#### Sample Input/Output:<n>Example #1<n>Input: A: Cats do not purr. B: Fish can smell. C: Cows need to be milked. D: Elephants can only sleep for two hours at a time.<n>Output: A: cat(D):  true B: fish(E): false C:  cow(F): false D: elephant(H): false<n>#### Solution:<n>**code**<n>```python<n>if s == 'cat': <n>        return True<n>```<n>```python<n>return s<n><n>else:<n>        return 'BLANK'<n>```

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers. How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:How would someone feel after going for run? Choices:  A: working out B: sore C: get tired D: satisfaction E: falling down<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>"""This script should have 9 lines of code<n><n>import random<n>import time,<n><n>num_runs = 10<n>num_participants = 10<n><n>for i in range(num_runs):<n>    run_time = time.time()<n>    while i+1 >= num_participants:<n>       # print choice and get index on line 9<n>       choice = int(input("How would you fee after going for a run? "))<n>       if choice == 'A':<n>          break<n>       elif choice == 'B':<n>            break<n>       elif choice === 'C':<n>            break<n><n>    i = i+1<n><n>print("Your score is {}\n".format(run_time - time.time()))<n>```<n><n>**Hint:** Don't use any import statement other than the first. You don't need more than a couple of imports. If you use too many, you will not be able to meet the time requirement. I would recommend using `random` only when it is essential, for example, to decide the number of participants.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:The competition was to see who would be the last one the drop the object, the hard part was you had to have your arm extended straight out while what the object? Choices:  A: holding B: lift up C: pick up D: lifting E: hold onto<n><n>### Response:		<n>- A<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## #Demonstration 2<n><n>### Demnstration: Write a program that determines which of the choices is the correct input that was provided in the demonstration.<n>- 9/13<n><n>### Inputs: There are 544 cows in a pen. 212 are cows, 234 are pigs, and 98 are sheep. How many animals other than sheep or cattle in the herd?<n><n>### Response Codes:<n>- 0: there is no other animals that is of the class animal<n>- 1: one other animal that is of animal class<n>- 2: two other animals that is of animal class, <n>- 3: three other animals that is of class animal<n>- 4: Above three choices if the above three choices<n>+ 1: is an animals that is in class animal <n>+ 2: are animal in class animal<n>+ 3: are animals in the class animal<n><n>### Example Output<n>1. Input: There are 5 dogs in a pen, 3 are male. How many dogs are female?<n>2. Response: 1<n><n>## Instruction: This question is a special type of Multiple-Choice Question. There will be 5 different options, all of which are true statements. Choose the most accurate statement.<n><n>## Demonstration Instruction:Write a program that finds the correct input.<n><n>### The contestants were on a bicycle race, one person was in first place, they were biking at 24 mi/hr., the second place person was biking at 12 mi/hr., and the third place person biking at 8 mi/hr. When a couple bike miles, which person is at the same place as the first person, if it is one hour, if it is half hour, is the person in the third place? Explain<n>The person in the first place will not be in same place as the second person, the third place will be the person who was biking at the fastest speed which is the first place.<n><n>### Input<n>Input: There are five candidates competing for a scholarship, in the scholarship exam:<n>1. There were

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:What is a convenient place for a bus station? With how many hours he can make 26 apples pies?<n><n>###  Instructi0n2:Rearrange the words and phrases in the parentheses to complete the sentence in the best order. The answer that is written as (b) in the brackets will have the correct answer.<n>The boy, who is playing (a) the piano, is (b) the winner of the competition<n><n>### Instruci0n:Choose the word on the right that has the underlined word in the same or nearly the same meaning as the given word. Use context to find the best choice.<n><n>###    Instruction:What is the best way to describe the relationship between a girl and her grandmother?<n><n>A)Grandmother and granddaughter are very close.<n>B)Grandmother is a girl's mother.<n>C)Grandmother raises a girl.<n>D)Grandmother loves a girl very much.<n>E)Grandmother helps a girl in the future.<n><n>### Answer must be E

If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:How do you indicate that you agree wtih someone? How many nickels does she have.<n><n>Input: Jennifer has 25 cents and 8 pennies. She has lost her change and she wants to know how much she has?<n><n>Answer: $0.25<n><n>Input: How much money does she have if she takes 21 cents and two nickels out?<n><n>Answer: $-0.07<n><n>Input: How would the money change if she put two quarters in?<n><n>Answer: Not applicable<n><n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>### Response 1:<n><n>### Instructon:<n><n>### Question:<n><n>### Answer:<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input:Where do you buy a glass of wine? Choices:  A: art show B: basement C: bar D: church E: basement<n><n>### Response:		<n><A>A: Answer: B. Basement. (The phrase where do you buy a glass... means where do you buy a 'glass of wine' which is why I used the word 'glass' instead of the full phrase. Since you're just buying 1 glass at a time, you can't buy glasses at a bar. Bars only serve large amounts of wine, and if that's not the case there definitely won't be any glasses. You could buy a glass of wine at an art show or a basement, where wine is sometimes served)<n><n><C>C: Answer: C. Church. (You can't buy wine at a church)<n><n><D>D: Answer: A. Art Show. (Because the answer is basement)<n><n><E>E: Answer: C. Bar. (The phrase where you buying a glass... would refer to multiple glasses of wine, since that's what a bar serves. You're not buying 1 glass, but 1 glass, 2 glasses... so it would mean buying a glass from the bar)<n><n>
